citations.narrative:
The inventory the licensee provided does not have the required information showing where the animals came from and
when they were acquired. Lack of acquisition information doesn't allow for proper tracking by APHIS officials. All
acquisition information must be documented for all regulated animals. Correct by 7/24/25.

citations.desc: Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.
citations.narrative:
The licensee was unable to find the Program of Veterinary Care. Not being able to produce a Program of Veterinary Care
during inspection doesn't allow for APHIS officials to ensure the animals are being cared for as per the instructions of the
Attending Veterinarian. The licensee must find and produce the Program of Veterinary Care at the next inspection. If the
Program of Veterinary Care can't be found, then the licensee must have the Attending Veterinarian fill out a new Program
of Veterinary Care. Correct by 7/24/25.

The licensee's contingency plan consists of just four names of people and the cities they live in. There is nothing showing
a chain of command, nothing that shows how the animals will be handled in the event of an emergency or disaster,
nothing describing what might trigger the need for executing a contingency plan, or nothing showing the tasks that might
need to be carried out in the event of an emergency or disaster. Not having a contingency plan in accordance with the
Animal Welfare Act doesn't ensure the facility will be prepared in the event of an emergency or disaster. The licensee
must complete the contingency plan in accordance with the requirements outlined in the Animal Welfare Act. Correct by
7/24/25.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
End of report.
